Title of Image: Section of Wall Street palisade
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: A section of the Wall Street palisade, 1600s

Title of Image: The Castello Plan, New Amsterdam in 1660
Source: © Collection of the New-York Historical Society/Bridgeman Art Library
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: In 1653, Africans built a wall along the northern edge of New Amsterdam to protect the Dutch community from the English. It stretched from the Hudson River clear across the island to the East River.

Title of Image: Current view of Wall Street
Creator: Manjari Sharma, photographer
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: The wall became Wall Street, which is now the financial capital of the world. Up until the Civil War and long after slavery in New York was illegal, Wall Street firms profited from the slave trade.

Title of Image: Current view of Maiden Lane
Creator: Manjari Sharma, photographer
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: Maiden Lane once included an orchard, where enslaved Africans and two Native Americans met to plan the rebellion. Today the lane is part of downtown’s financial district.

Title of Image: New York in 1712
Creator: Illustration by Bob Powers
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: On the night of April 6, 1712, a large well-planned and violent uprising began on Maiden Lane, which at that time ran along the northern edge of the city.

Title of Image: 369th Armory
Source: Military Photograph Collection/The New York Public Library
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: The 369th Regiment, or the “Harlem Hellfighters,” was the first African American regiment to fight in World War I. Their bravery in France won them that nation’s highest honor.

Title of Image: Current view of 369th Armory
Creator: Manjari Sharma, photographer
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: The 369th Regiment Armory is located at One West 142nd Street. Across from the armory is a memorial to the Harlem Hellfighters. The black granite obelisk is a replica of one in France.

Title of Image: Abolitionist Place, Brooklyn. Fulton and Duffield Street.
Source: Mid-Manhattan Library/Picture Collection/The New York Public Library
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: The neighborhood around Duffield Street was a hotbed of antislavery activity. At the Plymouth Church of the Pilgrims, mock slave auctions raised money and a “panic of sympathy.”

Title of Image: Current view of Abolitionist Place site
Creator: Manjari Sharma, photographer
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: In the fall of 2007, a new street sign went up. “Abolitionist Place,” at Willoughby and Duffield Streets, honors the brave antislavery efforts of this neighborhood in the 1800s.

Title of Image: Abyssinian Baptist Church in New York City, 1921
Current view of Abyssinian Baptist Church
Creator: Manjari Sharma, photographer
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: In 1923, the congregation moved into the Tudor Gothic–style church at 132 West 138th Street (Odell Clark Place),  where it became the largest and most influential black church in New York.

Title of Image: African-American congregation in front of Abyssinian Baptist Church at Waverly Place, New York City, c. 1907
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: Founded in 1808 and located on Worth Street, the Abyssinian Baptist Church first moved to 166 Waverly Place (pictured) and then farther north to West 40th Street in 1902.

Title of Image: African Free School, engraving
Source: Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture / Manuscripts, Archives and Rare Books Division/ The New York Public Library.
Creator: Patrick Reason
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: This picture of African Free School #2 is based on a drawing by one of its students named Patrick Reason. He, like many of his fellow students, went on to become a leading abolitionist.

Title of Image: Current view of African Free School site
Creator: Manjari Sharma, photographer
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: African Free School #2 was located at 135-137 Mulberry Street in the neighborhood then known as Five Points. All together, there were at least seven African Free Schools in the city.

Title of Image: Henry Highland Garnet
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: A photo of Henry Highland Garnett published in 1887

Title of Image: Henry Highland Garnet Colorized
History of New York African Free-Schools
James Hewlett as Richard the third
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: James Hewlett (1778–1836) played Richard the III (pictured) and other starring roles at the African Grove Theater. The audience loved the shows but the neighbors didn’t.

Title of Image: Current view of African Grove Theater site
Creator: Manjari Sharma, photographer
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: The first African Grove Theater was located on Mercer Street near Houston. It was built on the second floor of a two-story house with a large tea garden in back.

Title of Image: Playbill from the African Grove Theatre in Greenwich Village, ca. 1821
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: A program from the African Grove Theatre in Greenwich Village, ca. 1821

Title of Image: Ira Aldridge as "Othello"
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: Ira Aldridge as "Othello"

Title of Image: Portrait of Juliet Noel (Mrs Pierre Toussaint)
Source: © Collection of the New-York Historical Society/Bridgeman Art Library
Creator: Anthony Meucci
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: Juliet Toussaint, a member of the growing Haitian community in New York, donated money for the African Hall for Mutual Relief in 1820. The hall was located at 42 Baxter Street.

Title of Image: Current view of where the African Society for Mutual Relief once stood
Creator: Manjari Sharma, photographer
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: The New York African Society for Mutual Relief at 42 Baxter Street was targeted in two riots in the 1800s. It later moved uptown and survived until 1945.

Title of Image: View of Bedford-Stuyvesant
Creator: Manjari Sharma, photographer
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: What began in the 1830s as a small, rural black community in Weeksville  has grown into Bedford-Stuyvesant, home of the largest concentration of blacks in the city and one of the largest in the nation.

Title of Image: Current view of Restoration Plaza, Bedford-Stuyvesant
Creator: Manjari Sharma, photographer
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: Today a new pride can be felt in the community. At Restoration Plaza, a cultural center located at 1368 Fulton Street, a banner declares “Bed-Stuy and Proud of It.”

Title of Image: Black Brigades. Book of Negroes, Loyalist refugees from New York, in 1783.
Source: © Nova Scotia Museum 2008. All rights reserved. Nova Scotia Archives, Halifax
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: The handwritten “Book of Negroes” lists the names of some 3,000 African Americans who left New York City with the British. The book is located in the National Archives in Washington, D.C.

Title of Image: Current view of 10 Church Street, site of the Black Brigades' barracks
Creator: Manjari Sharma, photographer
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: During the Revolution, many members of the Black Brigades or Black Pioneers who fought with the British lived in “Negro barracks” at 10 Church Street and elsewhere.

Title of Image: Where Bridge Street AWME Church once stood
Creator: Manjari Sharma, photographer
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: Runaway slaves were once hidden in the basement of the Bridge Street Church at 311 Bridge Street. Today the site is the Student Center of Polytechnic University.

Title of Image: Bridge Street AWME Church today
Creator: Manjari Sharma, photographer
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: Today the Bridge Street AWME Church is located at 277 Stuyvesant Avenue, where it continues to attract many new parishioners from Africa and Latin America.

Title of Image: Catherine Ferguson
Source: © Collection of the New-York Historical Society/Bridgeman Art Library
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: Catherine Ferguson, or “Katy” as she was called, was determined from the age of 8 to gain her freedom and make the world a better place. She did both.

Title of Image: Current view of where Catherine Ferguson's home stood
Creator: Manjari Sharma, photographer
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: Children, both black and white, came to Ferguson’s home at 51 Warren Street to learn to read the bible. Some say this was the first Sunday school in New York City.

Title of Image: The riots in New York: destruction of the Colored Orphan Asylum
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: On July 13, 1863, as 233 children were led from the back door to safety, a white mob attacked the Colored Orphan Asylum and burned it to the ground during the city’s deadliest riot.

Title of Image: Current view of where the Colored Orphan Asylum once stood
Creator: Manjari Sharma, photographer
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: In 1863, the Colored Orphan Asylum was located on Fifth Avenue between 43rd and 44th Streets. From there it moved to Harlem and finally to the Bronx.

Title of Image: The riots in New York : conflict between the military and the rioters in First Avenue
David Ruggles
Creator: Illustration by Bob Powers
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: David Ruggles was the leading, and possibly the most hated, abolitionist in New York City. His courage, activism, and writings made the city a safer place for fugitives and free blacks.

Title of Image: Current view: the site of David Ruggles' House
Creator: Manjari Sharma, photographer
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: Ruggles sheltered runaway Frederick Douglass here at 36 Lispenard Street. He also ran a boarding house at 67 Lispenard that was a meeting place for abolitionists.

Title of Image: New York Committee of Vigilance, 1st Annual Report
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: Title Page:  The first annual report of the New York Committee of Vigilance for the year 1837 : together with important facts relative to their proceedings

Title of Image: George Downing’s Oyster House
Source: © Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture/Art Resource
Creator: Thomas Downing
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: Thomas Downing rowed out to the boats to pick over the oysters before the ships reached the oyster barges along the East River. Downing’s Oyster House served only the best.

Title of Image: Current view of where Downing's Oyster House stood
Creator: Manjari Sharma, photographer
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: Downing’s Oyster House was located at 5 Broad Street, but his basements, where fresh oysters were stored and escaping slaves were hidden, included numbers 3, 5, and 7 Broad Street.

Title of Image: Duke Ellington (1899-1974)
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: Duke Ellington was a composer, musician, and bandleader who changed the sound of American music and took its new sound around the world.

Title of Image: Current view of Duke Ellington Memorial
Creator: Manjari Sharma, photographer
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: The Duke Ellington Memorial towers 25 feet over Duke Ellington Circle. It is located at the northeast corner of Central Park at 110th Street and 5th Avenue.

Title of Image: Portrait of Duke Ellington
Source: Columbia University Rare Book and Manuscript Library:  Alexander Gumby Collection

Title of Image: Execution Grounds:  Foley Square
Creator: Illustration by Bob Powers
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: During the hysteria of the “Great Negro Plot,” 17 African Americans were hung and 13 were burned at the stake. The execution grounds were located on the African Burial Ground.

Title of Image: Current view of Execution Grounds: Foley Square
Creator: Manjari Sharma, photographer
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: What was the execution grounds in 1741 is now Foley Square, located between Lafayette and Centre Streets. The four white people convicted in the plot were hung near the East River.

Title of Image: Midsummer in the Five Points.
Source: Mid-Manhattan Library/Picture Collection/The New York Public Library
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: In the 1830s, free blacks and Irish and German immigrants lived crowded together in Five Points. “The most dangerous place in the city” was also a safe haven for those escaping slavery.

Title of Image: Current view of the Five Points intersection
Creator: Manjari Sharma, photographer
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: Five Points got its name from 5 corners where Anthony (now Worth) Street, Orange (now Baxter) Street, and Cross Street (which no longer exists) met.

Title of Image: Midsummer in the Five Points
Creator: C.A. Keetels, Artist

Title of Image: Five Points: Stereoscopic Photo
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: Five Points

Title of Image: View of New Amsterdam
Source: © Collection of the New-York Historical Society/ The Bridgeman Art Library
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: This picture shows Fort Amsterdam, and the Dutch Church built within it, behind a row of houses. On the shore you can see the company weighing beam and a tall crane used to unload cargo.

Title of Image: Current view of the Fort Amsterdam site
Creator: Manjari Sharma, photographer
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: The site of Fort Amsterdam, once used as a refuge for white settlers from Native Americans, is now occupied by the Museum of the American Indian.

Title of Image: Fort Amsterdam and village, New York
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: Fort Amsterdam and village, New York

Title of Image: Fraunces Tavern - Long Room
Creator: Richard Drew
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: Samuel Fraunces, known as “Black Sam,” bought 54 Pearl Street for a tavern in 1762. Well known in its day, Fraunces Tavern became famous for the history made there.

Title of Image: Current view of Fraunces Tavern
Creator: Manjari Sharma, photographer
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: Today Fraunces Tavern is a museum operated by the Sons of the Revolution. Built in 1719 as an elegant home, the building is one of the oldest standing in Manhattan.

Title of Image: Fraunces' Tavern, N.Y.C., 1777
Creator: Samuel Hollyer, Artist
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: Fraunces' Tavern, N.Y.C., 1777.

Title of Image: Portrait of Frederick Douglass
Source: Columbia University Rare Book and Manuscript Library:  Alexander Gumby Collection

Title of Image: Current view of David Ruggles' House, where Frederick Douglass was sheltered
Creator: Manjari Sharma, photographer
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: Frederick Douglass found a refuge from slave catchers when he met David Ruggles who welcomed him into his home at 36 Lispenard Street. Today a plaque there tells the story.

Title of Image: Portrait of Frederick Douglass
Source: Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture/Photographs and Prints Division/The New York Public Library
Creator: John Chester Buttre, Engraver
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: Born in 1818, Frederick Douglass was the most famous African American of the 19th century and has been called the father of the civil rights movement.

Title of Image: Published text of a speech by Frederick Douglass
Source: Columbia University Rare Book and Manuscript Library:  Alexander Gumby Collection
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: Published text of a speech by Frederick Douglass in the nation's capital on the anniversary of emancipation

Title of Image: Rev. Samuel Cornish
Source: © Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture/Art Resource
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: Samuel E. Cornish, a preacher (pictured), and John Brown Russwurm, a scholar, founded the nation’s first black newspaper in 1827. They called it Freedom’s Journal.

Title of Image: Current view of 236 Church St., former offices of Freedom's Journal
Creator: Manjari Sharma, photographer
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: The offices for Freedom’s Journal moved around. This location is 236 Church Street. Another office was located at 152 Church Street a few blocks farther downtown.

Title of Image: John B. Russwurm
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: John B. Russwurm

Title of Image: Langston Hughes with others overlooking St. Nicholas Avenue.
Source: Regina Andrews Photograph Collection/Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture/Photographs and Prints Division/ The New York Public Library
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: Author Langston Hughes with (left to right) Charles S. Johnson, E. Franklin Frazier, Rudolph Fisher, and Hubert T. Delaney. All were part of the Harlem Renaissance.

Title of Image: Statue of Adam Clayton Powell
Creator: Manjari Sharma, photographer
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: Visitors to Harlem today can find information at a kiosk at 163 W. 125th Street, the Adam Clayton Powell State Office Building. There you can also see a statue of Powell.

Title of Image: Harlem's 125th Street, 1949
Creator: Nichols, Photographer
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: 125th Street in Harlem,  September 17, 1949

Title of Image: Harriet Tubman and Family
Creator: William Cheney, Photographer
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: Left to right: Harriet Tubman; Gertie Davis [Tubman's adopted daughter]; Nelson Davis [Tubman's husband]; Lee Cheney; "Pop" Alexander; Walter Green; Sarah Parker ["Blind Auntie" Parker] and Dora Stewart [granddaughter of Tubman's brother, John Stewart]

Title of Image: Current view of 143 Nassau Street, once site where Tubman would bring people fleeing on the underground railroad.
Creator: Manjari Sharma, photographer
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: Harriet Tubman often stopped at the New York Anti-Slavery offices such as the one at 143 Nassau Street. There she and her passengers could get train or boat tickets to Canada and freedom.

Title of Image: Harriet Tubman; "The Moses of her people"; Herself a fugitive, she abducted more than 300 slaves, and also served as a scout and nurse for the Union forces
Source: Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture/General Research and Reference Division/The New York Public Library
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: Harriet Tubman was one of the greatest conductors on the Underground Railroad. After emancipating herself, she returned south 19 times to help as many as 300 others gain their freedom.

Title of Image: Hughson’s Tavern
Creator: Illustration by Bob Powers
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: Hughson’s Tavern was on the waterfront in 1741. Its doors were open to blacks and poor whites, making it suspect during “The Great Negro Plot” of 1741.

Title of Image: Current view of where Hughson's Tavern once stood
Creator: Manjari Sharma, photographer
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: Today, the site of Hughson’s Tavern at the corner of Liberty and Trinity Streets is far from the waterfront. What was once the location of docks for ships is now the site of the former World Trade Center.

Title of Image: Engraving of James McCune Smith
Source: Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture/Manuscripts, Archives and Rare Books Division/The New York Public Library
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: Dr. James McCune Smith was the first licensed African American doctor in the country. This portrait was created by Patrick Reason, a friend and fellow student at the African Free School.

Title of Image: Current view of James McCune Smith Pharmacy site
Creator: Manjari Sharma, photographer
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: The pharmacy of Dr. McCune Smith was located at 93 West Broadway. Many of the leading abolitionists and activists of the time met in his library in a back room.

Title of Image: Peter Williams, c.1810 (oil on canvas)
Source: © Collection of the New-York Historical Society/Bridgeman Art Library
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: The John Street Church welcomed Peter Williams and other African worshipers, but blacks and whites were segregated. In the early 1800s, a group separated to form the first black church in the state.

Title of Image: Current view: the site of John Street Methodist Church
Creator: Manjari Sharma, photographer
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: Today the John Street Church is still located at 44 John Street. It includes the Wesley Chapel Museum, which tells the story of the “The Oldest Methodist Congregation in America.”

Title of Image: Methodist Church, John Street, 1768
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: Methodist Church, John Street, 1768

Title of Image: Peter Williams, the old colored sexton of the John St. Methodist Church
Creator: Alexander Hay Ritchie, Engraver
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: Peter Williams, the old colored sexton of the John St. Methodist Church

Title of Image: Langston Hughes    June 1958  on the steps in front of his house in Harlem.
Source: © Robert W. Kelley/Time & Life Pictures/Getty Images
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: Langston Hughes wrote poems, plays, operas, short stories, children’s books, and more. And when he wasn’t writing, he lectured. Hughes was a major force behind the Harlem Renaissance.

Title of Image: Current view of Langston Hughes' former home
Creator: Manjari Sharma, photographer
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: Langston Hughes’s home at 20 East 127th Street is a New York City landmark, and the street has been renamed “Langston Hughes Place” in his honor.

Title of Image: Portrait of Younger Langston Hughes
Source: Columbia University Rare Book and Manuscript Library:  Alexander Gumby Collection
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: This photo of Langston Hughes was taken in 1930, when he was 28 years old.

Title of Image: "They're Our Kids!" by Langston Hughes
Source: Columbia University Rare Book and Manuscript Library:  Alexander Gumby Collection
Creator: Sunday Worker; Feb. 2, 1936
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: An example of how Langston Hughes mixed poetry and political activism, this poem is in honor of Ozie Powell, one of 9 African-American boys arrested together in 1931 after being falsely accused of rape in Scottsboro, Alabama.

Title of Image: Lewis Latimer photograph
Source: Queens Borough Library, Long Island Division. Latimer Family Papers.
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: Lewis H. Latimer was a brilliant inventor especially known for his work in electricity. Before Latimer, a light bulb might last only a day or two.

Title of Image: Current view of the Lewis H. Latimer House Museum
Creator: Manjari Sharma, photographer
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: The Lewis H. Latimer House Museum is located at 34-41 137th Street in Flushing, Queens, and is open by appointment.

Title of Image: Photo of Louis Armstrong
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: Louis Armstrong toured the globe playing his coronet for fans ranging from royalty to neighborhood kids. Millions knew him as “Ambassador Satch” or simply “Satchmo.”

Title of Image: Current view of Louis & Lucille Armstong's home
Creator: Manjari Sharma, photographer
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: The home of Louis and Lucille Armstrong located at 34-56 107th Street in Queens is a National Historic Landmark and museum. A tour of the home is like visiting the Armstrongs.

Title of Image: Marcus Garvey in full uniform
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: A black nationalist, Marcus Garvey immigrated to Harlem in 1916. There he established Liberty Hall as headquarters for a movement that would grow to almost 2 million members.

Title of Image: Current view of Marcus Garvey Memorial Park
Creator: Manjari Sharma, photographer
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: The Marcus Garvey Memorial Park interrupts Fifth Avenue between 120th and 124th Streets. Its 70-foot hill offers a view of the site of Garvey’s Liberty Hall on West 138th Street.

Title of Image: Advertisement for a UNIA Convention
Source: Columbia University Rare Book and Manuscript Library:  Alexander Gumby Collection
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: A 1924 UNIA flyer announces "Biggest Negro Convention in the History of the World: Program for Big Conclave Outlined"

Title of Image: Envelope for Donations to UNIA
Source: Columbia University Rare Book and Manuscript Library:  Alexander Gumby Collection
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: An envelope calling for joining and contributing to the Universal Negro Improvement Association

Title of Image: Portrait of James Varick
Creator: Illustration by Bob Powers
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: The first black church in the state was the Mother AME Zion Church located at 158 Church Street. James Varick was its first bishop.

Title of Image: Current view of the Mother A.M.E. Zion Church on 137th Street
Creator: Manjari Sharma, photographer
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: The present Mother AME Zion Church is located at 140-7 W. 137th Street. The building was designed by George W. Foster, Jr., one of the first black architects to be licensed in the U.S.

Title of Image: Founders of the AME Zion Church in New York
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: Bishop J. Varrick, No.1, A Founder. Bishop C. Rush, No.2, A Founder. Mother Church, in N. Y. Bishop Wm. Miller, No.3, A Founder. Bishop G. Galbreath, No.4, A Founder

Title of Image: James Varick
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: James Varick. First Bishop of the African Methodist Episcopal Zion Church.

Title of Image: The riots in New York : conflict between the military and the rioters in First Avenue
Source: Mid-Manhattan Library/Picture Collection/ The New York Public Library
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: During the Draft Riots of 1863, Union troops were called in to restore order. Here the rioters (pictured) battled Union forces along First Avenue, between 11th and 14th Streets.

Title of Image: Gramercy Park today
Creator: Manjari Sharma, photographer
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: Today, Gramercy Park is a quiet place, but in 1863 it was a war zone. Union cavalry and artillery occupied the park, setting up two cannon at the northeast corner to face the rioters.

Title of Image: Pierre Toussaint (1778-1853) c.1825
Source: © Collection of the New-York Historical Society/Bridgeman Art Library
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: When Pierre Toussaint was brought to New York from Haiti, he was enslaved. And yet his accomplishments in New York were so remarkable that he may become the first Haitian saint.

Title of Image: Historic marker honoring Pierre Toussaint, St. Patrick's Old Cathedral
Creator: Manjari Sharma, photographer
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: In 1953, this marker was laid in Toussaint’s honor at St. Patrick’s Old Cathedral at 263 Mulberry Street. His remains were later moved to the crypt below the altar of the current St. Patrick’s Cathedral.

Title of Image: Rikers Island - Black soldiers, Civil War, training
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: In 1864, the 26th Regiment of the U.S. Colored Troops trained on Rikers Island. They went on to fight, along with 180,000 other black soldiers, for the Union cause.

Title of Image: A map showing present-day Rikers Island
Creator: TK
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: Located in the East River near Long Island Sound, Rikers Island can be reached by bridge from Queens, but it is considered to be part of the Bronx.

Title of Image: Photo of Oyster Workers, 1894.
Source: Courtesy Alice Austen Collection, Staten Island Historical Society.
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: The people of Sandy Ground built one of the only free black communities to exist in the early 1800s. Oyster gatherers, such as these from Maryland, helped the community grow.

Title of Image: A map showing Sandy Ground in the present
Creator: TK
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: The Sandy Ground Historical Society Museum and Library is located at 1538 Woodrow Road. Here, one can explore the culture and history of this free black community.

Title of Image: Portrait of Arthur Schomburg
Source: Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture/Photographs and Prints Division/The New York Public Library
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: Known as “The Father of Black History,” Arthur Schomburg collected everything he could find on black culture. His collection grew into a great research library in Harlem.

Title of Image: Current view of the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture
Creator: Manjari Sharma, photographer
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: The Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture is located at 515 Malcolm X Boulevard at 135th Street. The library includes 6 million items from books to music, photographs, films, and artwork

Title of Image: Seneca Village
Creator: Illustration by Bob Powers
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: This map (pictured) shows Seneca Village, a largely black community that thrived from 1825 until 1855,  when the land was made part of Central Park by the city.

Title of Image: Current view of the Seneca Village site
Creator: Manjari Sharma, photographer
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: Today, as you walk in Central Park near West Drive and 85th Street, you can see a plaque commemorating Seneca Village.

Title of Image: Fernando Wood, Mayor of the City of New York
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: Fernando Wood, Mayor of the City of New York

Title of Image: Portrait of Henry Highland Garnet
Source: Humanities and Social Sciences Library/Print Collection, Miriam and Ira D. Wallach Division of Art, Prints and Photographs/The New York Public Library
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: The Shiloh Presbyterian Church was part of the Underground Railroad and led by three great abolitionists: Samuel Cornish, Theodore Wright, and the fiery Henry Highland Garnet (pictured).

Title of Image: Current view of Shiloh Presbyterian Church
Creator: Manjari Sharma, photographer
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: Over time the Shiloh Church moved north to Five Points, and then to Midtown. In 1895, members of the church founded St. James Presbyterian Church, now located at 409 W. 141st St.

Title of Image: Three-quarter length portrait of Sojourner Truth
Source: Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture/Photographs and Prints Division/The New York Public Library
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: Born a slave in 1797 in Ulster County, New York, Sojourner Truth spoke out against slavery and injustice, and for women’s rights, making people from President Lincoln to street toughs listen.

Title of Image: Current view of the site of Sojourner Truth's former home
Creator: Manjari Sharma, photographer
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: While living in New York City, Isabella Baumfree became Sojourner Truth and left her home at 74 Canal Street to spread the “Lord’s truth.” She became a legend in her own time.

Title of Image: St. Philip’s Episcopal Church. John F.E. Prud’homme engraving after William Bayley image.
Source: © Collection of the New-York Historical Society/Bridgeman Art Library
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: St. Philip’s Episcopal Church was a black center for worship, mutual aid, and activism throughout the 1800s. It was located at 31 Centre Street between Worth and Leonard until 1886.

Title of Image: Current view of St. Philips Episcopal Church
Creator: Manjari Sharma, photographer
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: Located at 204 W. 134th Street, the present church building is a New York City Designated Landmark. It was designed by the first African American architect licensed in New York.

Title of Image: St. Philip's P.E. Church, 1925
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: St. Philip's P.E. Church, 1925

Title of Image: Street Story Quilt,  Parts 1,2 3. 1. The Accident, 2. The Fire, 3. The Home Coming. 1985
Source: Collection of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
Creator: Faith Ringgold
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: From its beginnings in a rented loft, the Studio Museum in Harlem has shown the work of black artists, including Faith Ringgold’s Street Story Quilt (pictured).

Title of Image: A current view inside the Studio Museum in Harlem
Creator: Manjari Sharma, photographer
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: The Studio Museum in Harlem is now located at 144 W. 125th Street. It shows the work of emerging black artists as well as the work of well-known artists from their permanent collection.

Title of Image: A current view of the African Burial Ground Memorial
Creator: Manjari Sharma, photographer
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: The African Burial Ground National Monument memorial is located at Duane and Elk Streets. An exhibit at the visitor center is located at 290 Broadway on the ground floor.

Title of Image: African Burial Ground
Creator: Illustration by Bob Powers
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: For most of the 1700s, and maybe earlier, Africans and their descendents kept their own burial ground north of the city and its wall. As in Africa, the coffins were laid facing east.

Title of Image: The Audubon Ballroom
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: The Audubon Ballroom included a theater as well as meeting halls. Many labor, political, and religious groups met there, including Malcolm X’s Organization of Afro-American Unity.

Title of Image: A current view of the Audubon Ballroom
Creator: Manjari Sharma, photographer
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: The site now boasts the Malcolm X and Dr. Betty Shabazz Memorial and Educational Center, where three multi- media kiosks provide the largest exhibit on Malcolm X in the world.

Title of Image: The Castello Plan, New Amsterdam in 1660
Source: © Collection of the New-York Historical Society/Bridgeman Art Library
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: The Gideon, carrying 291 enslaved Africans, arrived at the Great Dock in 1664. Africans did most of the labor needed by the Dutch West India Company in New Amsterdam.

Title of Image: Current view of where the Great Dock once was
Creator: Manjari Sharma, photographer
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: In 1659, when Africans built the Great Dock, Pearl Street was the water’s edge.  The dock was located between today’s Whitehall Street and Broad Street, which was a canal.

Title of Image: City Hall and Great Dock, 1679
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: City Hall and Great Dock, 1679

Title of Image: Land of the Blacks
Creator: Manjari Sharma, photographer
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: The Land of the Blacks included parts of Chinatown, Little Italy, SoHo, and Greenwich Village. Washington Square Park (pictured) includes land once owned by five Africans.

Title of Image: Current view of Minetta Lane, once central to the Land of the Blacks
Creator: Manjari Sharma, photographer
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: Minetta Lane is a remnant of a road, later called the Negroes’ Causeway, that ran alongside Minetta Creek and connected some of the African farms with New Amsterdam.

Title of Image: Current view of a downtown area once supplied with water by the Manhattan Company
Creator: Manjari Sharma, photographer
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: The Manhattan Company’s water system, which never worked very well, was replaced in 1842 when fresh drinking water began to flow into the city from Croton.

Title of Image: Laying of the Water Pipes
Creator: Illustration by Bob Powers
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: Around 1801 workers lay log water pipes along Broad Street as officials from the Manhattan Company look on. The workers laid 25 miles of pipe in the city’s first water system.

Title of Image: The Slave Market
Creator: Illustration by Bob Powers
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: The Slave Market, located where Wall Street reached the East River, was established in 1711 as a place where enslaved blacks and Native Americans could be hired or purchased.

Title of Image: Current view of the site of the Slave Market
Creator: Manjari Sharma, photographer
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: Today, the site of the Slave Market, located at the intersection of Wall Street and Water Street, is far from the water’s edge.

Title of Image: New York slave market about 1730
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: New York slave market about 1730

Title of Image: Arthur Tappan
Source: © Collection of the New-York Historical Society/Bridgeman Art Library
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: Arthur (pictured) and his brother Lewis were both staunch abolitionists. Lewis also formed a company that would become Dun and Bradstreet.

Title of Image: Current view of the site of the Tappan Brothers' offices
Creator: Manjari Sharma, photographer
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: The offices of Arthur and Lewis Tappan were located at 122 Pearl Street. When pro-slavery mobs attacked during the riots of 1834, clerks fought them off with firearms.

Title of Image: Lewis Tappan
Death of Captain Ferrer, the Captain of the Amistad, July 1839
Creator: John Warner Barber, Lithographer
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: Death of Captain Ferrer, the Captain of the Amistad, July 1839

Title of Image: Runaway slave posters
Source: Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture /General Research and Reference Division/The New York Public Library
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: Theodore S. Wright was born free and was well educated, but he risked his own home and well-being every time he helped a runaway reach freedom in Canada.

Title of Image: Current view of the Theodore Wright house
Creator: Manjari Sharma, photographer
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: Wright’s home at 235 W. Broadway was part of the Underground Railroad at a time when slave catchers roamed the streets of the city and kidnapped runaways to return them south.

Title of Image: Charles B. Ray
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: Free Negroes in the Crisis; Charles B. Ray

Title of Image: Runaway Poster
Tontine Coffee House, c.1797 (oil on linen),
Source: © Collection of the New-York Historical Society/Bridgeman Art Library
Creator: Francis Guy
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: In 1792, the New York Stock Exchange was located in the Tontine Coffee House at 82 Wall Street.  Slave ships were registered here and a value was assigned to the Africans on board.

Title of Image: Current view of the Tontine Coffeehouse site
Creator: Manjari Sharma, photographer
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: In the 1790s, the Tontine Coffee House was only one block from the East River. By 1820, it was 2 blocks from the river as landfill widened Manhattan Island.

Title of Image: Tontine Coffee House, N.Y.C., 1820
Creator: Samuel Hollyer, Engraver
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: Tontine Coffee House, N.Y.C., 1820

Title of Image: Portrait of a woman
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: This unidentified photograph was found in Weeksville, one of the earliest free black communities in the country. Located in Brooklyn, it was a refuge for those fleeing both slavery and racism.

Title of Image: Current view of the Hunterfly road houses, Weeksville
Creator: Manjari Sharma, photographer
Caption (for CCI images, this is the the: You can visit the Weeksville Heritage Center located at 1698 Bergen Street between Rochester and Utica Avenues to see the three restored Hunterfly Road Houses.
